Steve, this is just a point on semantics really, but still 
interesting.  Y=
ou say that "inputs were not properly propagated."  
It's worth noting that=
 many researchers would actually say the 
opposite: They would say that thi=
s form of iterative propagation 
(wherein activation does not go all the wa=
y through the network in one 
fell swoop) *is* the proper form of propagati=
on, whereas the 
alternative is not proper.  The reason is that biology wor=
ks this 
way.  Biological neural networks are never "completely activated."=
  
They simply continaully activate forever (until death).  Thus one 
doesn=
't generally think of such networks in terms of completing the 
activation =
cycle properly.  Rather the network is in an infinite 
processing loop.  Of=
 course I realize that you understand this 
already, but it's just an inter=
esting cultural point since from your 
perspective that is not the correct =
way to activate a network. 

In fact, in some ways it is inaccurate to thin=
k of a network with a 
long delay line as not propagating to the outputs ov=
er the course of 
the delay because a neural network can have multiple para=
llel routes 
to the outputs, some longer than others.  The consequence is t=
hat you 
can react to an input faster with less processing than you can wit=
h 
more processing.  So the speed of thought comes into play.  

If someone=
 throws a ball at my head, I need to reflexively jerk my 
head to the side.=
  The neural path to that decision has to be pretty 
short.  On the other h=
and, the very same sensory event may trigger a 
more complicated chain of r=
easoning about who is doing this to me and 
why.  Both paths can start at t=
he same time even though one completes 
well before the other.  So in fact =
a neural network may well be 
returning output even while some signals from=
 the same trigger point 
in time are still traveling in another part of the=
 brain.  These 
nuances are lost in the all-at-once model.

Ultimately thou=
gh as I said there is no right way to do it.  It just 
depends on what you =
care about.  I can appreciate from a game design 
standpoint why one might =
choose to do it the way with which you are 
more familiar, because it could=
 save cycles on the CPU.  That's a 
valid consideration and there's nothing=
 wrong with it.

ken
